BA1.definition: Allele frequency greater than 5% in a population database
BA1.definitionLong: Allele frequency is > 5% in ExAC, 1000 Genomes, or ESP

BS1.definition: MAF is too high for disorder
BS1.definitionLong: Allele frequency greater than expected due to disorder

BS2.definition: Observation in controls inconsistent with disease penetrance
BS2.definitionLong: Observed in a healthy adult individual for a recessive (homozygous), dominant (heterozygous), or X-linked (hemizygous) disorder, with full penetrance expected at an early age

BS3.definition: Well-established functional studies show no deleterious effect
BS3.definitionLong: Well established in vitro or in vivo functional studies show no damaging effect on protein function or splicing

BS4.definitionLong: Lack of segregation in affected members of family (has caveat)

BP1.definition: Missense in gene where primarily truncating cause disease
BP1.definitionLong: Missense variant in a gene for which primarily truncating variants are known to cause disease

BP2.definition: Observed in trans with path. variant for dominant disorder or cis any inheritance
BP2.definitionLong: Observed in trans with a pathogenic variant for a fully penetrant dominant gene/disorder or observed in cis with a pathogenic variant in any inheritance pattern

BP3.definition: In-frame indels in repeat w/out known function
BP3.definitionLong: In-frame deletions/insertions in a repetitive region without a known function

BP4.definition: Multiple lines of computational evidence suggest no impact on gene /gene product
BP4.definitionLong: Multiple lines of computational evidence suggest no impact on gene or gene product (conservation, evolutionary, splicing impact, etc.) (has caveat)

BP5.definition: Found in case with an alternate cause
BP5.definitionLong: Variant found in a case with an alternate molecular basis for disease

BP6.definition: Reputable source w/out shared data = benign
BP6.definitionLong: Reputable source recently reports variant as benign, but the evidence is not available to the laboratory to perform an independent evaluation

BP7.definition: Silent variant predicted with no splice impact
BP7.definitionLong: A synonymous (silent) variant for which splicing prediction algorithms predict no impact to the splice consensus sequence nor the creation of a new splice site AND the nucleotide is not highly conserved

PP1.definition: Cosegregation with disease in multiple affected family members
PP1.definitionLong: Cosegregation with disease in multiple affected family members in a gene definitively known to cause disease

PP2.definition: Missense in gene with low rate of benign missense variants and path. missenses common
PP2.definitionLong: Missense variant in a gene that has a low rate of benign missense variation and in which missense variants are a common mechanism of disease

PP3.definition: Multiple lines of computational evidence support a deleterious effect on the gene /gene product
PP3.definitionLong: Multiple lines of computational evidence support a deleterious effect on the gene or gene product (conservation, evolutionary, splicing impact, etc.) (has caveat)

PP4.definition: Patient's phenotype or FH highly specific for gene
PP4.definitionLong: Patient's phenotype or family history is highly specific for a disease with a single genetic etiology

PP5.definitionLong: Reputable source recently reports variant as pathogenic, but the evidence is not available to the laboratory to perform an independent evalutation

PM1.definition: Mutational hot spot or well-studied functional domain without benign variation
PM1.definitionLong: Located in a mutational hot spot and/or critical and well-established functional domain (e.g. active site of enzyme) without benign variation

PM2.definitionLong: Absent from controls (or at extremely low frequency if recessive) in ExAC, 1000 Genomes, or ESP

PM3.definition: For recessive disorders, detected in trans with a pathogenic variant
PM3.definitionLong: For recessive disorders, detected in trans with a pathogenic variant

PM4.definitionLong: Protein length changes as a result of in-frame deletions/insertions in a non-repeat region or stop-loss variant

PM5.definition: Novel missense change at an amino acid residue where a different pathogenic missense change has been seen before
PM5.definitionLong: Novel missense change at an amino acid residue where a different missense change determined to be pathogenic has been seen before

PM6.definitionLong: Assumed de novo, but without confirmation of maternity/paternity

PS1.definition: Same amino acid change as an established pathogenic variant
PS1.definitionLong: Same amino acid change as a previously established pathogenic variant regardless of nucleotide change (has caveat)

PS2.definitionLong: De novo (both maternity and paternity confirmed) in a patient with the disease and no family history

PS3.definition: Well-established functional studies show a deleterious effect
PS3.definitionLong: Well established in vitro or in vivo functional studies supportive of a damaging effect on the gene or gene product

PS4.definition: Prevalence in affecteds statistically increased over controls
PS4.definitionLong: The prevalence of the variant in affected individuals is significantly increased compared with the prevalence in controls

PVS1.definition: Predicted null variant in a gene where LOF is a known mechanism of disease
PVS1.definitionLong: Null variant (nonsense, frameshift, canonical +/- 1 or 2 splice sites, initiation codon, single or multiexon deletion) in a gene where LOF is a known mechanism of disease (has caveats)
